comment_text.mn23:1.3: “Kassapa the Prince” (Kumārakassapa) was ordained at twenty (Kd 1:75.1.1). His verses are collected in the Theragāthā (Thag 2.41). His love of elaborate similes and playful similes is shown in the Pāyāsisutta (DN 23), and echoed here in the teachings to him. He was declared the foremost of those with brilliant speech (AN 1.217). | The Dark Forest (andhavana) was a thick grove south of Sāvatthī often visited by monks and nuns for meditation. However, this is the only discourse where someone is said to be staying there. The commentary says the name means “Blind Man’s Forest”, giving a highly improbable origin story. But compare Sanskrit andhakūpa, “dark well” or “blind well”, a well covered over with a lid or overgrowth; also the name of a hell.
comment_text.mn23:1.4: The deity offers a series of obscure riddles full of secret meaning, almost like a dream sequence. The deliberate use of obscurity is a hallmark of Brahmanical literature, for “the gods love hidden things” (parokṣakāmā hi devāḥ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 10.6.2.2 and throughout). The sequence is set out as a quest for buried treasure. This mytheme is implicit in the Vedic myth of Indra freeing the cattle and the sun from the Vala cave, an act that liberates the truth. Sometimes it is made explicit, as when Indra is said to bring up the treasures buried deep (Rig Veda 8.66.4). The Aśvins are also associated with unearthing buried gems (Rig Veda 1.117.5) or gold (Rig Veda 1.117.12), imagery ultimately based in mining for the wealth of minerals underground.
comment_text.mn23:2.1: Worship of termite mounds and the deadly snakes they harbor is still common in India today and is probably pre-Vedic. The Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa acknowledges a ritual significance to the anthill as a creative manifestation of the earth upon which offerings may be laid and whose ants were divine (2.6.2.17, 6.3.3.5, 14.1.2.10). In Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.7, Yājñavalkya compares a dead body bereft of soul to the lifeless slough of a snake on an anthill. | While anthills don’t “fume” and “flame”, large termite mounds leverage the temperature differential of day and night to create convection flows that regulate temperature and flush carbon dioxide.
comment_text.mn23:2.3: The sword is taken up, a symbol whose roots lie in the discovery of metal smelting and the power this grants to the one who wields the sword. But the phrase has a double meaning, for sattha means both “sword” and “sacred treatise”, while abhikkhaṇa means both “dig” (abhi + √khaṇ) and “see” (abhi + √ikkh; this sense not in Pali, but cf. Vedic abhikhyā). Thus, having entered the Dark Wood, the “clever one” (sumedha) is urged to use the wisdom of scripture in order to see. This sense is reinforced by the fact that is the “brahmin” who says this.
comment_text.mn23:2.4: Laṅgi occurs only here, and is glossed by the commentary with paligha (“obstacle”). Such an obscure term must have been selected for a play on words. Sanskrit lagna has the primary sense “to stick, adhere”, while also having a sense of the beginning or coming into contact with something. In modern languages such as Hindi, Marathi, or Kannada it has taken on the sense of “marriage”, and perhaps here we see an anticipation of this. If we are on the right track, the laṅgi would be the initial challenge for a mendicant seeker, namely their attachment to family. This would explain why it is the first obstacle.
comment_text.mn23:2.9: The male Indian bullfrog possesses a pair of prominent dark-blue vocal sacs that puff up and down as it croaks, hence the Pali name uddhumāyika (“puffer”). | Rig Veda 7.10 is addressed to frogs, who lie fallow in the dry but spring to life in the rains, filling the countryside with their amorous croaks, like the brahmin priests reciting their verses and passing them down to students.
comment_text.mn23:2.14: Rig Veda 10.88.15 speaks of the two paths of gods and mortals (devānām uta martyānām), later formalized as the path of the forefathers (pitṛyāna) leading to rebirth and that of the gods (devayāna) leading to liberation. This corresponds to the twofold choice of the young Siddhattha: to stay at home or to go forth.
comment_text.mn23:2.19: Caṅgavāra is a filter through which, according to Ja 525:29.2, water drips away like the brief days of our lives. The commentaries say that such alkaline (khāra) filters were used by laundrymen. This refers to the traditional method of creating lye (a soap precursor) for washing, where a barrel is filled with wood ash through which water is passed. No matter how many pots of water are poured in, the commentary adds, it keeps dripping.
comment_text.mn23:2.24: As described in Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 7.5.1, a tortoise was placed on the altar to represent the primordial powers of creation: the sap of life, the sun, the breath, and the act of creation itself. Its lower and upper shells and its body in-between correspond to the three worlds: the earth, the heavens, and the midspace. It therefore connotes the ancient, endless movement of life.
comment_text.mn23:2.29: In this brutal simile, asi is a knife and sūna is a place where animals are slaughtered, either a slaughterhouse or, as here, an implement for the slaughter. Mnd 1:23.18 says this phrase has the meaning of “chopping” (adhikuṭṭanaṭṭhena). Compare with asiṁ sūnāṁ in the violent, sexually graphic hymn at Rig Veda 10.86.18c. Vedic sūna was a (sewn) “basket” for carrying the flesh of a slaughtered beast (see also Rig Veda 1.161.10), a sense that developed to “chopping block” and “slaughterhouse”. Jamison and Brereton read the Vedic passage as an analogy for the horse sacrifice, at the climax of which the queen has vulgar and very public sex with the dead horse. This cements in the most explicit way possible the oneness of sexual potency with the cycle of life and death.
comment_text.mn23:2.34: Another simile shared with MN 22:3.10. A maṁsapesi is small enough to be grabbed by a crow (MN 54:16.1), or to quickly disintegrate on a stove (AN 7.74:7.1), thus is a “scrap of meat” rather than a substantial piece. It emphasizes the meanness and poverty of mortal life, our desires and attachments bound up with this transient “scrap of meat” we call a body.
comment_text.mn23:2.39: Nāga here means both a cobra—the literal snake that lives underneath an anthill—and the serpent of mysterious power that is analogous to an arahant, the “spiritual giant”.
comment_text.mn23:2.44: This is, of course, a direct slight on the brahmins who prided themselves on finding explanations for the most obscure and puzzling passages.
comment_text.mn23:4.1: Just as a termite mound is created by activity driven by eating and excreting, so this body is created from within by food. Also, the body, like a termite mound, is home to countless small creatures.
comment_text.mn23:4.2: Apparently stressing oneself at night over work is not a modern phenomenon.
comment_text.mn23:4.13: The bullfrog (uddhumāyika) evokes those renunciates who become puffed up (uddhata) and argumentative over doctrines (eg. Thag 17.1:11.1).
comment_text.mn23:4.19: The commentary says that, just as water continually drips through such a filter, the mind of someone beset by the five hindrances cannot stay fixed internally on what is wholesome. This contrasts with the mind in absorption, which is illustrated with similes of water that emphasize stillness and containment (DN 2:76.1, etc.).
comment_text.mn23:4.23: The five aggregates are the tortoise’s five limbs, with consciousness as the head. The aggregates represent the changing world of conditions driven by karma, just as the tortoise is the creative force and life of the three worlds. In samādhi, the senses are withdrawn like a tortoise’s limbs (SN 35.240:1.4).
comment_text.mn23:4.27: The senses work because the sense stimulus smashes into the sense organ, like a knife on a chopping block. We seek pleasurable sensations to mask the inherently turbulent nature of sense experience.

root_text.mn23:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn23:1.3: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā kumārakassapo andhavane viharati.
root_text.mn23:1.4: Atha kho aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṁ andhavanaṁ obhāsetvā yenāyasmā kumārakassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho sā devatā āyasmantaṁ kumārakassapaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn23:2.1: “Bhikkhu bhikkhu, ayaṁ vammiko rattiṁ dhūmāyati, divā pajjalati.
root_text.mn23:2.4: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa laṅgiṁ
root_text.mn23:2.9: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa uddhumāyikaṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.14: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa dvidhāpathaṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.19: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa caṅgavāraṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.24: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa kummaṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.29: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa asisūnaṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.34: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa maṁsapesiṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.39: Abhikkhaṇanto sumedho satthaṁ ādāya addasa nāgaṁ.
root_text.mn23:2.42: ‘tiṭṭhatu nāgo, mā nāgaṁ ghaṭṭesi; namo karohi nāgassā’ti.
root_text.mn23:2.43: Ime kho tvaṁ, bhikkhu, pañhe bhagavantaṁ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi, yathā ca te bhagavā byākaroti tathā naṁ dhāreyyāsi.
root_text.mn23:2.44: Nāhaṁ taṁ, bhikkhu, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yo imesaṁ pañhānaṁ veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyya aññatra tathāgatena vā, tathāgatasāvakena vā, ito vā pana sutvā”ti—
root_text.mn23:3.1: Atha kho āyasmā kumārakassapo tassā rattiyā accayena yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā kumārakassapo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn23:3.2: “imaṁ, bhante, rattiṁ aññatarā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṁ andhavanaṁ obhāsetvā yenāhaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhitā kho, bhante, sā devatā maṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn23:3.3: ‘bhikkhu bhikkhu, ayaṁ vammiko rattiṁ dhūmāyati, divā pajjalati.
root_text.mn23:3.10: Ko nu kho, bhante, vammiko, kā rattiṁ dhūmāyanā, kā divā pajjalanā, ko brāhmaṇo, ko sumedho, kiṁ satthaṁ, kiṁ abhikkhaṇaṁ, kā laṅgī, kā uddhumāyikā, ko dvidhāpatho, kiṁ caṅgavāraṁ, ko kummo, kā asisūnā, kā maṁsapesi, ko nāgo”ti?
root_text.mn23:4.1: “‘Vammiko’ti kho, bhikkhu, imassetaṁ cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa adhivacanaṁ, mātāpettikasambhavassa odanakummāsūpacayassa aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammassa.
root_text.mn23:4.2: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhu, divā kammante ārabbha rattiṁ anuvitakketi anuvicāreti—
root_text.mn23:4.4: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhu, rattiṁ anuvitakketvā anuvicāretvā divā kammante payojeti kāyena vācāya manasā—
root_text.mn23:4.6: ‘Brāhmaṇo’ti kho, bhikkhu, tathāgatassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
root_text.mn23:4.12: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.15: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.18: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.19: ‘Caṅgavāran’ti kho, bhikkhu, pañcannetaṁ nīvaraṇānaṁ adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn23:4.22: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.23: ‘Kummo’ti kho, bhikkhu, pañcannetaṁ upādānakkhandhānaṁ adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn23:4.26: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.28: cakkhuviññeyyānaṁ rūpānaṁ iṭṭhānaṁ kantānaṁ manāpānaṁ piyarūpānaṁ kāmūpasaṁhitānaṁ rajanīyānaṁ,
root_text.mn23:4.32: kāyaviññeyyānaṁ phoṭṭhabbānaṁ iṭṭhānaṁ kantānaṁ manāpānaṁ piyarūpānaṁ kāmūpasaṁhitānaṁ rajanīyānaṁ.
root_text.mn23:4.34: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.37: abhikkhaṇa, sumedha, satthaṁ ādāyāti ayametassa attho.
root_text.mn23:4.39: Tiṭṭhatu nāgo, mā nāgaṁ ghaṭṭesi; namo karohi nāgassāti ayametassa attho”ti.
root_text.mn23:4.41: Attamano āyasmā kumārakassapo bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn23:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn23:1.3: Now at that time Venerable Kassapa the Prince was staying in the Dark Forest.
translation_text.mn23:1.4: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Dark Forest, went up to Kassapa the Prince, stood to one side, and said:
translation_text.mn23:2.1: “Monk, monk! This termite mound fumes by night and flames by day.
translation_text.mn23:2.3: ‘Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.4: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a sticking point:
translation_text.mn23:2.8: Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.9: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a bullfrog:
translation_text.mn23:2.13: Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.14: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a forked path:
translation_text.mn23:2.18: Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.19: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a filter of ash:
translation_text.mn23:2.23: Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.24: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a tortoise:
translation_text.mn23:2.28: Dig, clever one, having taken up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.29: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a butcher’s knife and chopping board:
translation_text.mn23:2.30: ‘A butcher’s knife and chopping board, sir!’
translation_text.mn23:2.32: ‘Throw out the butcher’s knife and chopping board!
translation_text.mn23:2.33: Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.34: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a scrap of meat:
translation_text.mn23:2.38: Dig, clever one, having picked up the sword!’
translation_text.mn23:2.39: Picking up the sword and digging, the clever one saw a cobra:
translation_text.mn23:2.42: ‘Leave the cobra! Do not disturb the cobra! Worship the cobra!’
translation_text.mn23:2.43: Mendicant, go to the Buddha and ask him about this riddle. You should remember it in line with his answer.
translation_text.mn23:2.44: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to this riddle except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.”
translation_text.mn23:2.45: That is what that deity said
translation_text.mn23:3.1: Then, when the night had passed, Kassapa the Prince went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he asked:
translation_text.mn23:3.10: “Sir, what is the termite mound? What is the fuming by night and flaming by day? Who is the brahmin, and who the clever one? What are the sword, the digging, the sticking point, the bullfrog, the forked path, the filter of ash, the tortoise, the butcher’s knife and chopping board, and the scrap of meat? And what is the cobra?”
translation_text.mn23:4.1: “Mendicant, ‘termite mound’ is a term for this body made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
translation_text.mn23:4.2: Thinking and considering all night about what you did during the day—
translation_text.mn23:4.3: this is the fuming at night.
translation_text.mn23:4.4: The work you apply yourself to during the day by body, speech, and mind after thinking about it all night—
translation_text.mn23:4.5: this is the flaming by day.
translation_text.mn23:4.6: ‘Brahmin’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn23:4.7: ‘Clever one’ is a term for the trainee mendicant.
translation_text.mn23:4.8: ‘Sword’ is a term for noble wisdom.
translation_text.mn23:4.9: ‘Digging’ is a term for rousing energy.
translation_text.mn23:4.10: ‘Sticking point’ is a term for ignorance.
translation_text.mn23:4.11: ‘Throw out the sticking point’ means ‘give up ignorance,
translation_text.mn23:4.12: dig, clever one, having picked up the sword.’
translation_text.mn23:4.13: ‘Bullfrog’ is a term for anger and distress.
translation_text.mn23:4.14: ‘Throw out the bullfrog’ means ‘give up anger and distress’ …
translation_text.mn23:4.16: ‘A forked path’ is a term for doubt.
translation_text.mn23:4.17: ‘Throw out the forked path’ means ‘give up doubt’ …
translation_text.mn23:4.19: ‘A filter of ash’ is a term for the five hindrances, that is:
translation_text.mn23:4.20: the hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
translation_text.mn23:4.21: ‘Throw out the filter of ash’ means ‘give up the five hindrances’ …
translation_text.mn23:4.23: ‘Tortoise’ is a term for the five grasping aggregates, that is:
translation_text.mn23:4.24: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn23:4.25: ‘Throw out the tortoise’ means ‘give up the five grasping aggregates’ …
translation_text.mn23:4.27: ‘Butcher’s knife and chopping board’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn23:4.28: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn23:4.32: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn23:4.33: ‘Throw out the butcher’s knife and chopping board’ means ‘give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation’ …
translation_text.mn23:4.35: ‘Scrap of meat’ is a term for greed and relishing.
translation_text.mn23:4.36: ‘Throw out the scrap of meat’ means ‘give up greed and relishing’ …
translation_text.mn23:4.38: ‘Cobra’ is a term for a mendicant who has ended the defilements.
translation_text.mn23:4.39: This is the meaning of: ‘Leave the cobra! Do not disturb the cobra! Worship the cobra!’”
translation_text.mn23:4.40: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn23:4.41: Satisfied, Venerable Kassapa the Prince approved what the Buddha said.
